Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Percutaneous Sciatic Nerve Peripheral Nerve Stimulation for Postoperative Analgesia in Ambulatory Foot Surgery

Participants.evidence: Adults scheduled for primary, unilateral hallux valgus osteotomy were eligible, excluding those with certain medical conditions or treatments.

Intervention.evidence: Seven participants were randomised to receive either 5 minutes of PNS or sham stimulation

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and analgesic efficacy of percutaneous sciatic nerve peripheral nerve stimulation (PNS) in ambulatory foot surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was pain reduction, measured using the numeric rating scale (NRS) over 40 minutes postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealed in opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Pain scores decreased to 52% of baseline during subsequent 30 minutes of stimulation.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included one lead dislodgement and three lead fractures.
